QuoteText: Yes, that makes a lot of sense. That is a topic (who/how decisions of abortion policy) that one can more reasonably argue than whether abortion is moral or not, though it takes more legal and constitutional law knowledge than (at least) I have. I do support a more pragmatic approach to this topic, along the lines of what do we actually need to do about this complex problem. Deciding what is a human or baby or what it feels or thinks is essentially an unanswerable issue. Interesting philosophical arguments to be sure, unless one wants to be dogmatic and insist their own is the only way to see things. The other issue of what constitutes a "human right" legal or constitutionally (or even if such a thing exists in those domains) is also an interesting topic, that I had not considered until now. Thanks for the clarification.

QuoteText: Uh, I'm confused. I keep hearing "the right to abortion" being thrown around. There is no "right to abortion". There is, however, a "right to privacy" and that's what Roe v. Wade was about. Though the right to privacy does have its limits.
ResponseText: The right to privacy (aka the right to abortion) was established in the griswold case...not roe. Futhermore, the section of roe you cited later was pretty much taken away by Casey....not only that, what the hell are the limits? No one seems to know.

ResponseText: Whether or not a man is in the relationship for the pregnancy doesn't change the fact that he doesn't go through it himself Also, if you're trying to get into the whole sex before/after marriage debate, I don't believe abortions are never carried out on married women, in the same way abortions are obviously not only performed on women who aren't in a relationship.

QuoteText: they should first of all be married... then he could be a real man and be a dad.
ResponseText: Real man??? Is that what getting married does for ya? Anyway, your answers to the questions posed to you seem to have a tense problem: ...then she/he/they should not have had sex in the first place ... should have used better birth control ... should first of all be married ... should have been in the ideal socio-economic position to have children as well as the ideal psychological position to desire and be able to care for children. These shoulds are all well and good and they have merit. In and of themselves they sometimes can be very good ideas; maybe not for everyone, but they certainly would decrease unwanted pregancies and/or the motivations for abortion. The problem is they are all after the fact. It makes no sense and is staggeringly unhelpful to spout these rather obvious platitudes when it is too later to enact them. What good is it to tell someone what they should have done after they have already done it?
